instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
Hello. Got an 820-2936 here that got fried by knockoff charger. ISL6269 was fried, Q7030 and Q7035 also fried. SMC is fried like KFC. I replaced ISL, replaced both mosfets and verified all current sensing resistors near ISL. Also replaced D6990, U6990 and Q7080 as they looked suspicious. At the present moment I got SMC out of the board and am working on establishing at least 12.24V on PPBUS_G3H line. My readings are as follows:

Got 16.5V from charger DCIN
PPBUS_G3H varies from 0.3V to 2V after some time charger is connected, if I heat up Q7080 I get immediately 12.24V on L7030 and steady 3.3V on L6995. I'm stuck now. Tried injecting 12.5V on L7030, I get a sparkle but it does not drain any current from my PSU. Any ideas on what to look?

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
"Tried injecting 12.5V on L7030, I get a sparkle but it does not drain any current from my PSU"
Don't try to bypass charger stage in such way.
You still have to repair it, even the rest of board is OK (or not).

Start checking resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of ISL6259.
Also post some voltages; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 19, 20.
Post exact value (ohm scale, measured onboard) for R7080/81 and R7085/86.

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
17/18 = 2.4Ohm
27/28 = 20.5Ohm
R7080 = 98K
R7081 = 61.4K
R7085 = 465K
R7086 = 331k

Voltages:

Pin 1 = 5mV
Pin 2 = 16.25V
Pin 3 = 3.86V
Pin 9 = 0V
Pin 12 = 228mV
Pin 13 = 229mV
Pin 14 = 228mV
Pin 15 = scaling up and down from 80mV to 400mV
Pin 19 = 5.06V
Pin 20 = 5.06V

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
"Pin 12 = 228mV
Pin 13 = 229mV"
Do you miss 3V42???

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 49249"]
Do you miss 3V42???[/QUOTE]

Yes, L6995 has 234mV

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
Solve that problem.
Post diode mode to ground first.
If no short/low value, post U6990 voltages.
Check R/D6990...

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
I replaced R6990 and D6990 before posting here because they were blown... I found a short to GND on ISL and its two mosfets which I replaced. The short on D6990 was cleared after replacing them and D6990 is not blowing anymore. Voltages for U6990(already replaced it twice) are:

Pin 1 = 1.204V
Pin 2 = 3.64V
Pin 3 = 12.30V
Pin 4 = oscillating between 15.95V and 16.22V
Pin 5 = 0V
Pin 6 = 270mV
Pin 7 = oscillating between 15.90V and 16.22V
Pin 8 = 3.71V
Pin 9 = 313mV
Pin 10 = 0V

Diode mode to GND on L6995 is 0.324(red probe on ground, black on coil) and OL (red on coil, black on ground)

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
Did you change C6996?
Also check all traces around U6990.
Be sure R6995 has correct value.

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: Yes, I checked C6996 and it's not shorted... R6995 is 1Mohm... Will take another look under the microscope on U6990 area...

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: Apparently all traces are good... Verified with multimeter in beep mode and everything is going where it's supposed...

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: Change C6996...

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: Replaced it and still same voltage on L6995, 0.355V

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: Change again U6990 and be sure is properly soldered...

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: Replaced it... Same results... I'm thinking the knockoff charger fucked the board internally...

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
How, if you didn't report any short?
Change L6995 now, or swap all pieces from similar board (same area).

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: From the same area do you mean L6995 area? Will do it!

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: I replaced L6995, C7940, R7941, R3305, C6996 and R6995. Same readings...

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
You miss something there.
If all changed, must get 3V42.
Post again diode mode on L6995 and all voltages for U6990...

Also compare diode mode (several points) and voltages with an working board.

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
Diode mode(red on GND, black on L6995) = 0.331

Unfortunately I do not have a working board of the same model here to compare now... If someone here got any and could share readings would be nice!

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
U6990 voltages:

Pin1 = 1.215V
Pin2 = 3.61V
Pin3 = 12.47V
Pin4 = 16.84V
Pin5 = 0V
Pin6 = 0.457V
Pin7 = 16.83V
Pin8 = 3.6V
Pin9 = 275mV
Pin10 = 0V

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: Now the thing got stranger! I re-soldered the SMC in place as I would give up and give this machine back to the costumer. When I reassembled the device, I put on the battery that had 60% of charge and on battery the machine powers on and I get beautiful 3.42V on L6995! The machine does not charge the battery though and neither gives green or orange light on charger, but this shit is working on battery now! What should be my next step?

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: Change R/D6990...

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message: Replaced both... Same results... Gave up on this one! Will give it back to costumer and move forward because the pile is getting bigger! Thanks for the help anyway.

threads.title: 820-2936 No Power
threads.message:
If the board works on battery only, then 3V42 power supply is OK.
You have a problem with the voltage coming from charger to 3V42 input...
